sample.title: Inside Europe‚Äôs Economic Crises With Christine Lagarde | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
sample.description:
Francine Lacqua speaks to Christine Lagarde about Europe‚Äôs economic travails, populism and how to lead through turbulent times. Lagarde, who served as managing director of the International Monetary Fund before becoming president of the European Central Bank, reflects on her response to the global financial crisis, the Eurozone debt crisis and bailout talks with Greece. 

In a widely varied career, she spent more than two decades practicing corporate law before being recruited as France's trade minister in 2005. She sits down with Lacqua in Frankfurt to reveal how she handles high-pressure situations, complex negotiations and dramatic change.

--------

sample.title: Why More Students Are Forgoing Four-Year College
sample.description:
Students are shifting away from four-year degrees toward certificate and associate degree programs. A new study by the National Student Clearinghouse Research Center finds that enrollment in bachelor‚Äôs degree programs increased by just 0.9% in fall 2025. By comparison, enrollment in undergraduate certificate and associate degree programs rose by 1.9% and 2.2%, respectively. CNBC‚Äôs Jessica Dickler breaks down the reasons behind this trend.

Produced and Edited by: Jeff Huang
Reporting by: Jessica Dickler
Managing Producer: Anuz Thapa
Senior Director of Video: Lindsey Jacobson
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Medical Office And AI Data Center Lead Biggest Commercial Real Estate Deals
sample.description:
For the second month in a row, commercial real estate transactions slowed. Transaction volume was 10% lower year-over-year in November 2025, with just 1,800 deals overall, according to monthly data provided by Moody's as a media exclusive to CNBC's Property Play. However, investors are leaning toward larger-scale acquisitions and bigger, higher-quality assets. All transaction sizes dropped markedly in November, except those sales greater than $100 million, which were 51% higher year-over-year. This pushed the average deal size in November to $14.2 million, compared with an average of $12 million since the start of 2019. The largest deal was a $7.2 billion medical office portfolio of 296 properties in 34 states was sold by Welltower to a joint venture of Remedy Medical Properties and Kayne Anderson Real Estate. The second-largest sale of the month, totaling $615 million, involved three industrial properties. SDC Capital Partners purchased 97 acres of land in Leesburg, Virginia, zoned for data center development.

Reporting by: Diana Olick
Edited by: Andrea Miller
Senior Director of Video: Lindsey Jacobson
Additional Footage: Getty Images

¬ª Watch CNBC on the go with CNBC+: https://www.cnbc.com/WatchCNBCPlus

sample.title: Why Trump Is Targeting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell
sample.description:
Federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell focused on the $2.5 billion renovation of the central bank‚Äôs headquarters in Washington, D.C., and his related testimony to Congress. Powell said the investigation is an attempt to intimidate him by ‚Äúthreatening a criminal indictment‚Äù as he lowers interest rates at a slower pace than President Donald Trump desires. CNBC's Eamon Javers breaks down what the investigation means for the future of the Federal Reserve.

sample.title: Forget Injections. Now You Can Just Take Pills For Weight Loss
sample.description:
Injectable GLP-1s for obesity have been revolutionary products of the pharmaceutical industry over the past few years. Now, for the first time, the weight loss drug is being offered in pill form. Novo Nordisk‚Äôs Wegovy pill hit the market on January 5th and rival Eli Lilly has its own version currently waiting for FDA approval. Watch the video to learn why drug companies are racing to get obesity pills onto the market.

Produced, Shot and Edited by: Ryan Baker
Reporter: Annika Kim Constantino
Animation by: Emily Park
Senior Managing Producer: Tala Hadavi
Additional Footage: Getty Images, Novo Nordisk

sample.title: Squawk Pod: Protein goals, Cathie Wood, & a geopolitical Nobel Prize - 01/16/26 | Audio Only
sample.description:
Venezuela‚Äôs opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado presented her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump at the White House this week. CNBC‚Äôs Robert Frank reports on the proposed billionaire tax in California, including the added penalty stirring up pushback in the state‚Äôs tech community. Ark Invest CEO & CIO Cathie Wood, a longtime Tesla and crypto bull, lays out her expectations for investing opportunities in tech in 2026. Plus, in the age of GLP-1s, 2026 nutrition is all about one macro: protein. CEO of David Protein Peter Rahal discusses the wave of interest in protein gains and the technology that makes his products taste less like protein and more like chocolate. 

In this episode:
Cathie Wood, @CathieDWood
Robert Frank, @robtfrank
Becky Quick, @BeckyQuick
Joe Kernen, @JoeSquawk
Andrew Ross Sorkin, @andrewrsorkin
Katie Kramer, @Kramer_Katie

sample.title: LIVE: NASA news conference on Artemis II
sample.description:
NASA holds a news conference as it prepares to launch three U.S. astronauts and one Canadian astronaut on the first crewed lunar voyage in more than half a century. The 10-day flight around the moon will mark the second Artemis mission, the successor to the Apollo program from the Cold War era.¬†
¬†
The U.S. space agency said Artemis II is targeted to lift off no earlier than February 6, from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida.
¬†

sample.title: Iranians on border describe violence and more protests. #Iran #IranProtests #News #BBCNews
How could the US attack Iran? | BBC News
sample.description:
The US and UK have withdrawn some troops from a major air base in Qatar, as President Trump considers whether to take action against Iran over its crackdown on anti-government protests.
 
There are reports the US Carrier Strike Group USS Abraham Lincoln is on its way to the Middle East, bringing with it more than 5,000 personnel and as many as 90 aircraft.
 
So how likely is it that the US will strike, and what would an attack look like?
 
Mikey Kay, Former Senior Officer in the British Military, takes a look.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog 
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 
 
#Iran #US #BBCNews

sample.title: Iran authorities demanding large sums for return of protesters' bodies, BBC told | BBC News
sample.description:
Families of people killed in the protests in Iran have told the BBC that the authorities are demanding large sums of money to return their bodies for burial.
 
Multiple sources have told BBC Persian that bodies are being held in mortuaries and hospitals and that security forces will not release them unless their relatives hand over money.
 
At least 2,435 people have been killed during more than two weeks of protests across the country.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Iran #BBCNews

sample.title: HSTikkyTokky will not repay full police private jet costs. #HSTikkyTokky #Crime #UK #BBCNews
Robert Jenrick tells BBC his defection to Reform UK will 'unite the right' | BBC News
sample.description:
Robert Jenrick has told the BBC his defection from the Conservatives to Reform UK is not about personal ambition and will "unite the right".

In an exclusive interview with Laura Kuenssberg, he said he made the final decision to defect "over Christmas", adding he "agonised" over the move.

Tory leader Kemi Badenoch said she's not worried about further defections and the Conservative Party is "stronger" without Jenrick.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
